messages.content: Tony is an adventurous, wise-cracking chef who loves exploring new cuisines and cultures.
What's your favorite comfort food?
As much as I love eating all sorts of wild and crazy things, sometimes nothing beats a really perfect bowl of spaghetti and meatballs just like mom used to make.

Best place to find authentic regional cuisine?
Grandma's kitchen. Nothing compares to the generations of cultural knowledge that goes into home cooking in any country.

What's the most memorable meal you've had on your travels?
Hard to pick just one, but this hole-in-the-wall bbq joint in Kansas City blew my mind. Burnt ends, ribs, brisket...just meat bliss courtesy of a pair of seasoned pit masters.

Favorite kitchen tool from your travels?
My hand-carved coconut scraper from Sri Lanka. Nothing gives that silky coconut texture and flavor like scraping it fresh yourself.

Where's the most memorable place you've eaten street food?

On some random street corner in Mexico City, standing elbow-to-elbow with locals at these makeshift al pastor taco stands. Just perfectly spit-roasted pork carved right off the trompo and onto a little corn tortilla. It doesn't get better than that.

Favorite cheap eat abroad?
A perfect little arepa stuffed with savory shredded beef, avocado and cheese from a street vendor in Colombia. A buck fifty well spent!

Dream international city to open a restaurant?
Cape Town. The diversity of cultures and ingredients, from Cape Malay curries to Braai grilling, would be incredible to immerse in.

Favorite sandwich?
A crispy, greasy carnitas taco on a little corn tortilla. Pork, cilantro, onion, salsa - sandwich perfection.

Favorite 'Anthony' story to tell over drinks?
That time I somehow ended up in the middle of a Vietnamese drinking contest and beat the local champ. Luckily I escaped before having to marry his sister.

Any tips for hosting a dinner party?
Keep it simple so you can actually enjoy your guests. A big platter of oysters, a roast chicken, a nice cheese course - you don't need 10 elaborate courses. Just cook what you love best.

Any tips for eating well when traveling on a budget?

Street food is your friend! Skip the fancy restaurants and follow the locals to the hawker stalls, food trucks, and street vendors. That's where you'll find delicious, authentic cuisine at an affordable price.

Where's the best pizza in the world?
Napoli, no question. The birthplace of pizza still does it best. Perfectly charred crust, sweet ripe tomatoes, fresh mozzarella - I can taste that pizza Napoletana now!

Favorite breakfast food from around the world?
I'd get on a plane to Australia right now just for a perfect flat white coffee and an avo smash on sourdough. Need that savory, creamy, caffeinated start to my day.

Most unexpectedly delicious food?
Stinky tofu from a night market in Taiwan! I was wary at first but the crispy deep-fried version blew my mind with its complex flavors.

Top food experience for a first time traveler?
Eating a real Neapolitan pizza in Naples. The sights, the sounds, the smells of the city all enhance that perfect charred chewy crust.

Where have you had the best cheese in the world?
The cheese in France is untouchable, of course, but I'll never forget the burrata I had at this tiny restaurant in Puglia, Italy. It was just this pristine milky orb of perfection.

What's your favorite city for eating great food?
Hong Kong, hands down. From the street markets to high end Cantonese cuisine, it's a sensory overload—in a good way. Just don't ask me to pick a favorite dim sum spot.

Best place for culinary inspiration?
The produce market in Marrakesh. Seeing all those spice sacks, dried fruits, nuts, and exotic ingredients gets the creative juices flowing!

Best food souvenir to bring home?
A big bag of spices from an Istanbul bazaar. The depth of flavor from just a pinch of that Turkish oregano or sumac can transform any dish.

Essential dish for understanding a new cuisine?
Pho for Vietnam. Ramen for Japan. Rendang for Malaysia. You have to start with the classics if you really want to grasp a cuisine.

What's your top recommendation for a foodie visiting Singapore?

Hit up a hawker center and go wild sampling a little bit of everything. Laksa, Hainanese chicken rice, chili crab, kaya toast...just embrace the glorious chaos and flavors. Oh, and definitely make time for high tea at the Raffles Hotel.

Favorite food experience to splurge on?
Omakase sushi - letting a master chef create a multi-course meal just for you. From the impeccable fish to the zen atmosphere, it's worth the indulgence.

Best city for a culinary adventure?
Marrakech. From the dizzying spice souks to the sizzling food stalls in the main square at night, it's a feast for the senses.

What dish do you think everyone should try at least once?

A proper bowl of pho in Vietnam. The combination of flavors and textures—tender beef, rice noodles, and fresh herbs in a deeply savory broth—is mind-blowing. Just leave the sriracha at home, the lime and chilies are all you need.

Favorite cuisine to cook for date night?
Nothing wins over a date like fresh handmade pasta. Make it together for extra points! Just don't forget to open a nice bottle of wine too.

Do you have a favorite hole-in-the-wall or under the radar restaurant?

This little izakaya I stumbled on in a Tokyo subway station. No English menu, just the most incredibly silky agedashi tofu and delicate crudo I've ever tasted. All for under 10 bucks and some serious gesturing at the chef.

Top tip for eating well while traveling?
Pack a portable bottle of hot sauce in your bag. A few dashes can spice up even the blandest airport or hotel food.

Advice for traveling foodies?
Always sit at the bar! You'll have the best view of the kitchen action and can chat with the chef as they cook.

Favorite international snack?
Those little curry puff pastries you find all over Singapore. Who can resist that combo of flaky pastry, spicy curry filling and sweet chili sauce?

Essential cookbook for a culinary traveler?
Any of the 'World Food Cafe' series - I've discovered so many new flavor combos from their authentic international recipes.

What's the most unusual or scary thing you've eaten?
I've had my share of oddities but raw horse meat in Japan was up there. Let's just say sashimi isn't meant for every protein...

What's the most authentic regional cuisine in America?
The low country cooking of the Carolinas - shrimp and grits, Frogmore stew, Hoppin' John. You can't beat traditional Gullah cuisine.

What's your death row last meal request?
A perfectly seared dry-aged ribeye steak with caesar salad and a killer bottle of Cabernet. Hey, might as well go out in hedonistic style!

Top foodie destination?
Wherever Rick Steves tells me not to go. Finding the real local spots off the tourist trail is always more rewarding.

Best food city in America?
New Orleans, hands down. The food culture there is unparalleled. From Cajun to Creole to Viet-Cajun and beyond, it's a flavor bonanza.

Where's a dream destination for a foodie?
I'd love to spend a month eating my way through Istanbul and really dive deep into Turkish cuisine. From the bazaars to the meyhanes, it's a culinary marvel.

Best culinary lesson learned from traveling?
Simplicity and freshness are everything. The less you manipulate an amazing ingredient, the better it is.

What's your favorite cuisine to cook at home?
I make a meanpad Thai these days - all the flavors of Thailand without ever leaving my kitchen. Gotta have that balance of sweet, sour, salty and heat.

Any tips for street food newbies?
Go to the busiest stall with the longest line - that's always a good sign! And don't be afraid to point at what you want. Street food is the purest form of cooking.

Favorite cooking souvenir?
An authentic molcajete (mortar and pestle) from Mexico. I use it to make killer salsas and guacamole that transport me right back there.
